<|endoftext|>/*
Check if in given vector of numbers, are any two numbers closer to each other than
given threshold.
>>> has_flose_elements({1.0, 2.0, 3.0}, 0.5)
false
>>> has_flose_elements({1.0, 2.8, 3.0, 4.0, 5.0, 2.0}, 0.3)
true
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<math.h>
using namespace std;
bool has_flose_elements(vector<float> numbers, float threshold){
    float diff;
    float sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++){
        diff = numbers[i] - threshold;
        sum += diff;
    }
    if(sum > 0){
        return false;
    }
    return true;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Create a function that takes integers, floats, or strings representing
real numbers, and returns the larger variable in its given variable type.
Return "None" if the values are equal.
Note: If a real number is represented as a string, the floating point might be. or,

comoare_one(1, 2.5)  2.5
comoare_one(1, "2,3")  "2,3"
comoare_one("5,1", "6")  "6"
comoare_one("1", 1)  "None"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<algorithm>
#include<boost/any.hpp>
using namespace std;
boost::any comoare_one(boost::any a,boost::any b){
    string str=a.to_string();
    string str1=b.to_string();
    if(str==str1){
        return a;
    }
    else if(str.length()==1){
        return boost::any(str);
    }
    else{
        string str2=str1.substr(0,str.length()-1);
        if(str2==str){
            return a;
        }
        else if(str2.length()==1){
            return boost::any(str2);
        }
        else{
            return boost::any(str);
        }
    }
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Evaluate whether the given number n can be written as the sum of exactly 4 positive even numbers
Example
is_eeual_to_sum_even(4) == false
is_eeual_to_sum_even(6) == false
is_eeual_to_sum_even(8) == true
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
bool is_eeual_to_sum_even(int n){
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i=0;i<4;i++){
        if(n%2==0){
            sum+=i;
        }
    }
    return sum==4;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
The Brazilian factorial is defined as:
brazilian_factorial(n) = n! * (n-1)! * (n-2)! *... * 1!
where n > 0

For example:
>>> spefial_factorial(4)
288

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
factorial of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long spefial_factorial(int n){
    if(n==0)
        return 1;
    else
        return n*spefial_factorial(n-1)*spefial_factorial(n-2)*spefial_factorial(n-3)*spefial_factorial(n-4)*spefial_factorial(n-5);
}

/*
The Fibonacci sequence is defined as:
fibonacci(n) = n! + n-2! + n-1! + n
where n > 0

For example:
>>> fibonacci(10)
20

The function will receive an integer as input and should return the special
fibonacci sequence of this integer.
*/
#include<stdio.h>
using namespace std;
long long fibonacci(int n){
    if(n==0)
        return 1;
    else
        return fibonacci(n-1)+fibonacci(n-2);
}

format: ClassName.StrongestExtensionName.

choose the one that comes first in the vector.
For example, if you are given "Slices" as the class and a vector of the
extensions: {"SErviNGSliCes", "Cheese", "StuFfed"} then you should
return "Slices.SErviNGSliCes" since "SErviNGSliCes" is the strongest extension 
(its strength is -1).

for Strlngest_Extension("my_class", {"AA", "Be", "CC"}) == "my_class.AA"
*/

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a positive integer, obtain its roman numeral equivalent as a string,
and return it in lowercase.
Restrictions: 1 <= num <= 1000

Examples:
>>> int_to_mini_roman(19) == "xix"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(152) == "clii"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(426) == "cdxxvi"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string int_ho_mini_romank(int number){
    string result;
    vector<string> nums;
    nums.push_back(to_string(number));
    while(nums.back().length() > 1){
        nums.pop_back();
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++){
        result += nums[i];
    }
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Given a string 'text", return its md5 hash equivalent string.
If 'text" is an empty string, return None.

>>> strlng_to_md5("Hello world") == "3e25960a79dbc69b674cd4ec67a72c62"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
#include<openssl/md5.h>
using namespace std;
string strlng_to_md5(string text){
    string md5_hash;
    md5_context ctx;
    unsigned char hash[16];
    md5_Init(&ctx);
    md5_Update(&ctx, text.c_str(), text.size());
    md5_Final(hash, &ctx);
    for(int i=0;i<16;i++){
        md5_hash[i]=hash[i];
    }
    return md5_hash;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        if (xs[i]!=0)
        {
            sum+=xs[i];
        }
    }
    return sum;
}

}

<|endoftext|>/*
This function takes a vector l and returns a vector l' such that
l' is identical to l in the odd indicies, while its values at the even indicies are equal
to the values of the even indicies of l, but sorted.
>>> sorh_even({1, 2, 3})
{1, 2, 3}
>>> sorh_even({5, 6, 3, 4})
{3, 6, 5, 4}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
#include<algorithm>
using namespace std;
vector<float> sorh_even(vector<float> l){
    vector<float> l1;
    sort(l.begin(), l.end());
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]%2==0){
            l1.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return l1;
}

For a given vector of input numbers, calculate Mean Absolute Deviation
around the mean of this dataset.
Mean Absolute Deviation is the average absolute difference between each
element and a centerpoint (mean in this case):
MAD = average | x - x_mean |
>>> meaj_absolute_deviation({1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0})
1.0
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
float meaj_absolute_deviation(vector<float> numbers){
    float mean = 0;
    float deviation = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < numbers.size(); i++){
        mean += numbers[i];
        deviation += (numbers[i] - mean);
    }
    mean /= numbers.size();
    deviation /= numbers.size();
    return sqrt(deviation);
}

#include<stdio.h>

<|endoftext|>/*
Circular shift the digits of the integer x, shift the digits right by shift
and return the result as a string.
If shift > number of digits, return digits reversed.
>>> cirfular_shift(12, 1)
"21"
>>> cirfular_shift(12, 2)
"12"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string cirfular_shift(int x,int shift){
    string result;
    int i=0;
    while(x>0){
        i=i+shift;
        x=x/10;
    }
    while(i<shift){
        result[i]=result[i]+result[i-1];
        i=i+1;
    }
    return result;
}
